segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 47
segments.en: Linked Discourses 47

segments.pli: 1. Ambapālivagga
segments.en: 1. In Ambapālī’s Wood

segments.pli: 9. Gilānasutta
segments.en: 9. Sick

segments.pli: Evaṃ me sutaṃ—
segments.en: So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati veḷuvagāmake.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the little village of Beluva.

segments.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

segments.pli: “etha tumhe, bhikkhave, samantā vesāliyā yathāmittaṃ yathāsandiṭṭhaṃ yathāsambhattaṃ vassaṃ upetha.
segments.en: “Mendicants, please enter the rainy season residence with whatever friends or acquaintances you have around Vesālī.

segments.pli: Idhevāhaṃ veḷuvagāmake vassaṃ upagacchāmī”ti.
segments.en: I’ll commence the rainy season residence right here in the little village of Beluva.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paṭissutvā samantā vesāliyā yathāmittaṃ yathāsandiṭṭhaṃ yathāsambhattaṃ vassaṃ upagacchuṃ.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” those mendicants replied. They did as the Buddha said,

segments.pli: Bhagavā pana tattheva veḷuvagāmake vassaṃ upagacchi.
segments.en: while the Buddha commenced the rainy season residence right there in the little village of Beluva.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavato vassūpagatassa kharo ābādho uppajji, bāḷhā vedanā vattanti māraṇantikā.
segments.en: After the Buddha had commenced the rainy season residence, he fell severely ill, struck by dreadful pains, close to death.

segments.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā sato sampajāno adhivāsesi avihaññamāno.
segments.en: But he endured with mindfulness and situational awareness, without worrying.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi:
segments.en: Then it occurred to the Buddha:

segments.pli: “na kho me taṃ patirūpaṃ, yohaṃ anāmantetvā upaṭṭhāke anapaloketvā bhikkhusaṃghaṃ parinibbāyeyyaṃ.
segments.en: “It would not be appropriate for me to become fully extinguished before informing my attendants and taking leave of the mendicant Saṅgha.

segments.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ imaṃ ābādhaṃ vīriyena paṭipaṇāmetvā jīvitasaṅkhāraṃ adhiṭṭhāya vihareyyan”ti.
segments.en: Why don’t I forcefully suppress this illness, stabilize the life force, and live on?”

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā taṃ ābādhaṃ vīriyena paṭipaṇāmetvā jīvitasaṅkhāraṃ adhiṭṭhāya vihāsi.
segments.en: So that is what he did.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavato so ābādho paṭippassambhi.
segments.en: Then the Buddha’s illness died down.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā gilānā vuṭṭhito aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā vihārā nikkhamitvā vihārapacchāyāyaṃ paññatte āsane nisīdi.
segments.en: Soon after the Buddha had recovered from that sickness, he left his dwelling and sat in the shade of the porch on the seat spread out.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

segments.pli: “diṭṭho me, bhante, bhagavato phāsu;
segments.en: “Sir, it’s fantastic that the Buddha is comfortable,

segments.pli: diṭṭhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato khamanīyaṃ;
segments.en: that he’s well,

segments.pli: diṭṭhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato yāpanīyaṃ.
segments.en: and that he’s alright.

segments.pli: Api ca me, bhante, madhurakajāto viya kāyo, disāpi me na pakkhāyanti, dhammāpi maṃ nappaṭibhanti bhagavato gelaññena.
segments.en: Because when the Buddha was sick, my body felt like it was drugged. I was disorientated, and the teachings didn’t spring to mind.

segments.pli: Api ca me, bhante, ahosi kācideva assāsamattā:
segments.en: Still, at least I was consoled by the thought that

segments.pli: ‘na tāva bhagavā parinibbāyissati, na yāva bhagavā bhikkhusaṃghaṃ ārabbha kiñcideva udāharatī’”ti.
segments.en: the Buddha won’t become fully extinguished without making some statement regarding the Saṅgha of mendicants.”

segments.pli: “Kiṃ pana dāni, ānanda, bhikkhusaṃgho mayi paccāsīsati?
segments.en: “But what could the mendicant Saṅgha expect from me now, Ānanda?

segments.pli: Desito, ānanda, mayā dhammo anantaraṃ abāhiraṃ karitvā.
segments.en: I’ve taught the Dhamma without making any distinction between secret and public teachings.

segments.pli: Natthānanda, tathāgatassa dhammesu ācariyamuṭṭhi.
segments.en: The Realized One doesn’t have the closed fist of a teacher when it comes to the teachings.

segments.pli: Yassa nūna, ānanda, evamassa:
segments.en: If there’s anyone who thinks:

segments.pli: ‘ahaṃ bhikkhusaṃghaṃ pariharissāmī’ti vā, ‘mamuddesiko bhikkhusaṃgho’ti vā, so nūna, ānanda, bhikkhusaṃghaṃ ārabbha kiñcideva udāhareyya.
segments.en: ‘I’ll take charge of the Saṅgha of mendicants,’ or ‘the Saṅgha of mendicants is meant for me,’ let them make a statement regarding the Saṅgha.

segments.pli: Tathāgatassa kho, ānanda, na evaṃ hoti:
segments.en: But the Realized One doesn’t think like this,

segments.pli: ‘ahaṃ bhikkhusaṃghaṃ pariharissāmī’ti vā, ‘mamuddesiko bhikkhusaṃgho’ti vā.
Sa kiṃ, ānanda, tathāgato bhikkhusaṃghaṃ ārabbha kiñcideva udāharissati.
segments.en: so why should he make some statement regarding the Saṅgha?

segments.pli: Etarahi kho panāhaṃ, ānanda, jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto.
segments.en: I’m now old, elderly and senior. I’m advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life.

segments.pli: Āsītiko me vayo vattati.
segments.en: I’m currently eighty years old.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, jajjarasakaṭaṃ veḷamissakena yāpeti;
segments.en: Just as a decrepit cart keeps going by relying on straps,

segments.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, veḷamissakena maññe tathāgatassa kāyo yāpeti.
segments.en: in the same way, the Realized One’s body keeps going by relying on straps, or so you’d think.

segments.pli: Yasmiṃ, ānanda, samaye tathāgato sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā ekaccānaṃ vedanānaṃ nirodhā animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharati, phāsutaro, ānanda, tasmiṃ samaye tathāgatassa kāyo hoti.
segments.en: Sometimes the Realized One, not focusing on any signs, and with the cessation of certain feelings, enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart. Only then does the Realized One’s body become more comfortable.

segments.pli: Tasmātihānanda, attadīpā viharatha attasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā, dhammadīpā dhammasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā.
segments.en: So Ānanda, be your own island, your own refuge, with no other refuge. Let the teaching be your island and your refuge, with no other refuge.

segments.pli: Kathañcānanda, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo, dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo?
segments.en: And how does a mendicant do this?

segments.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

segments.pli: vedanāsu … pe …
segments.en: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

segments.pli: citte … pe …
segments.en: mind …

segments.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
segments.en: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo, dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo.
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant is their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge. That’s how the teaching is their island and their refuge, with no other refuge.

segments.pli: Ye hi keci, ānanda, etarahi vā mamaccaye vā attadīpā viharissanti attasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā, dhammadīpā dhammasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā; tamatagge mete, ānanda, bhikkhū bhavissanti ye keci sikkhākāmā”ti.
segments.en: Whether now or after I have passed, any who shall live as their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge; with the teaching as their island and their refuge, with no other refuge—those mendicants of mine who want to train shall be among the best of the best.”

segments.pli: Navamaṃ.

suttaplex.blurb: The Buddha decides to spend his final rains retreat at Vesālī in Beluvagāmaka. During the retreat he becomes very ill, but later recovers. Ānanda wonders who will guide the Saṅgha when the Buddha dies, but the Buddha says they should be their own refuge, grounded on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
